submission_text: This change encourages innovation while maintaining consumer safeguards — a thoughtful approach.
The proposal is complex; we have no firm position until an impact assessment is published. Please include a public FAQ and an implementation timeline. (See clause 1.)
This proposal will disadvantage consumers and concentrate compliance costs on micro and small enterprises. (See clause 10.)
No strong view at this time; request clarification on clause 7 and guidance materials.
The definition changes in clause 2 are problematic and may lead to unintended legal consequences. Please consider a phased rollout for small enterprises.

The definition changes in clause 2 are problematic and may lead to unintended legal consequences. We find the proposed enforcement measures excessive. Penal provisions are not sufficiently calibrated and may result in punitive consequences for administrative errors rather than willful misconduct. Please consider a phased rollout for small enterprises.
This draft is a step in the right direction; the measures to protect user privacy are balanced and practical. We also request a clear grievance redressal mechanism.
The timelines are unrealistic and will create enforcement issues; the amendment needs substantial revision. (See clause 7.)
The draft is vague and introduces heavy administrative burdens; please reconsider the reporting requirements. Can the authorities publish an impact assessment?
The timelines are unrealistic and will create enforcement issues; the amendment needs substantial revision.
The amendments address the key concerns raised earlier; we strongly support adoption as written. Can the authorities publish an impact assessment?
The timelines are unrealistic and will create enforcement issues; the amendment needs substantial revision. This will require guidance for implementation at the state level.
The definition changes in clause 2 are problematic and may lead to unintended legal consequences.
We have mixed views: supportive of the objectives but concerned about operational complexity.
The draft is vague and introduces heavy administrative burdens; please reconsider the reporting requirements.

The proposal is complex; we have no firm position until an impact assessment is published. Please include a public FAQ and an implementation timeline. Please consider a phased rollout for small enterprises.
We strongly oppose this amendment. It will increase costs for small retailers and harm MSMEs. (See clause 2.)
I support the proposed amendment — it clarifies responsibilities and will improve compliance for small businesses. Please consider a phased rollout for small enterprises. (See clause 1.)
No strong view at this time; request clarification on clause 7 and guidance materials. Can the authorities publish an impact assessment?
We welcome the clarification in clause 4. It will reduce ambiguity and assist MSMEs to comply without heavy costs. Can the authorities publish an impact assessment?
This change encourages innovation while maintaining consumer safeguards — a thoughtful approach. Please consider a phased rollout for small enterprises.
No strong view at this time; request clarification on clause 7 and guidance materials.
The timelines are unrealistic and will create enforcement issues; the amendment needs substantial revision.

The draft is vague and introduces heavy administrative burdens; please reconsider the reporting requirements. We find the proposed enforcement measures excessive. Penal provisions are not sufficiently calibrated and may result in punitive consequences for administrative errors rather than willful misconduct.
It appears balanced in parts; however, the fiscal impact on small businesses is unclear.
This proposal will disadvantage consumers and concentrate compliance costs on micro and small enterprises.
The amendments address the key concerns raised earlier; we strongly support adoption as written. (See clause 4.)
I support the proposed amendment — it clarifies responsibilities and will improve compliance for small businesses.

We welcome the clarification in clause 4. It will reduce ambiguity and assist MSMEs to comply without heavy costs. The changes to reporting exceptions are welcome. Under the current system small firms struggle with ambiguous rules; this amendment provides clarity that will lower compliance costs and improve uptake of digital services. (See clause 6.)
The proposal is complex; we have no firm position until an impact assessment is published.
The timelines are unrealistic and will create enforcement issues; the amendment needs substantial revision. Can the authorities publish an impact assessment?
The amendments address the key concerns raised earlier; we strongly support adoption as written.

I support the proposed amendment — it clarifies responsibilities and will improve compliance for small businesses. The changes to reporting exceptions are welcome. Under the current system small firms struggle with ambiguous rules; this amendment provides clarity that will lower compliance costs and improve uptake of digital services. Please consider a phased rollout for small enterprises. (See clause 10.)
The proposal is complex; we have no firm position until an impact assessment is published. We also request a clear grievance redressal mechanism. (See clause 1.)

The definition changes in clause 2 are problematic and may lead to unintended legal consequences. We find the proposed enforcement measures excessive. Penal provisions are not sufficiently calibrated and may result in punitive consequences for administrative errors rather than willful misconduct.
The proposal is complex; we have no firm position until an impact assessment is published. Please consider a phased rollout for small enterprises.

The amendments address the key concerns raised earlier; we strongly support adoption as written. As a consumer advocate group, we believe the proposed amendment strikes the right balance between protecting personal data and allowing legitimate business use. We particularly support the retention limits introduced in Article 6, which are proportionate and evidence-based.
This draft is a step in the right direction; the measures to protect user privacy are balanced and practical.
We have mixed views: supportive of the objectives but concerned about operational complexity. Please include a public FAQ and an implementation timeline.
It appears balanced in parts; however, the fiscal impact on small businesses is unclear. (See clause 6.)
It appears balanced in parts; however, the fiscal impact on small businesses is unclear. (See clause 9.)
Neutral: the amendment seems reasonable but further detail on implementation timelines would help. Can the authorities publish an impact assessment?

The amendments address the key concerns raised earlier; we strongly support adoption as written. The changes to reporting exceptions are welcome. Under the current system small firms struggle with ambiguous rules; this amendment provides clarity that will lower compliance costs and improve uptake of digital services. This will require guidance for implementation at the state level.

We strongly oppose this amendment. It will increase costs for small retailers and harm MSMEs. This amendment, in its present form, will place disproportionate burdens on local vendors and small service providers. The cost estimates do not take into account the operational realities for micro-enterprises and therefore risk stifling competition. (See clause 7.)
We strongly oppose this amendment. It will increase costs for small retailers and harm MSMEs.
Neutral: the amendment seems reasonable but further detail on implementation timelines would help. This will require guidance for implementation at the state level.

This draft is a step in the right direction; the measures to protect user privacy are balanced and practical. As a consumer advocate group, we believe the proposed amendment strikes the right balance between protecting personal data and allowing legitimate business use. We particularly support the retention limits introduced in Article 6, which are proportionate and evidence-based. Please consider a phased rollout for small enterprises.
Neutral: the amendment seems reasonable but further detail on implementation timelines would help. (See clause 1.)

This proposal will disadvantage consumers and concentrate compliance costs on micro and small enterprises. We find the proposed enforcement measures excessive. Penal provisions are not sufficiently calibrated and may result in punitive consequences for administrative errors rather than willful misconduct. Please consider a phased rollout for small enterprises.
This draft is a step in the right direction; the measures to protect user privacy are balanced and practical.
